meta.name: Description

head.title: Softness- and Size-Dependent Packing Symmetries of Polymer-Grafted Nanoparticles | ACS Nano

meta.content: Softness- and Size-Dependent Packing Symmetries of Polymer-Grafted Nanoparticles

Achieving ordered arrays of nanoparticles (NPs) with controlled packing symmetry and interparticle spacing is of great importance to design complex metamaterials. Herein, we report softness- and size-dependent self-assembly behavior of polystyrene-grafted Au NPs (Au@PS NPs). We varied the core size of Au NPs from 1.9 to 9.6 nm and the number-average molecular weight (Mn) of thiol-terminated polystyrene from 1.8 to 7.9 kg mol–1. The optimal packing model based on an “effective softness” parameter λeff that accounts for close-packed and semidilute brush regimes could predict the effective radius of Au@PS NPs (within ±9%) for a wide range of PS Mn, grafting density, and Au core size. With increasing λeff, the self-assembled Au@PS NP superlattices undergo a symmetry transition from hexagonal close packed (hcp) to body-centered tetragonal (bct) to body-centered cubic (bcc). This work demonstrates the effective softness model as a simple but robust tool for the design of NP superlattices with precisely controlled interparticle distance and packing symmetry, both of which are critical for the development of sophisticated materials through control of nanoscale structure.

SUBJECTS:

div.p:
Achieving ordered arrays of nanoparticles (NPs) with controlled packing symmetry and interparticle spacing is of great importance to design complex metamaterials. Herein, we report softness- and size-dependent self-assembly behavior of polystyrene-grafted Au NPs (
[email protected]
NPs). We varied the core size of Au NPs from 1.9 to 9.6 nm and the number-average molecular weight (
M
n
) of thiol-terminated polystyrene from 1.8 to 7.9 kg mol
–1
. The optimal packing model based on an “effective softness” parameter λ
eff
that accounts for close-packed and semidilute brush regimes could predict the effective radius of
[email protected]
NPs (within ±9%) for a wide range of PS
M
n
, grafting density, and Au core size. With increasing λ
eff
, the self-assembled
[email protected]
NP superlattices undergo a symmetry transition from hexagonal close packed (hcp) to body-centered tetragonal (bct) to body-centered cubic (bcc). This work demonstrates the effective softness model as a simple but robust tool for the design of NP superlattices with precisely controlled interparticle distance and packing symmetry, both of which are critical for the development of sophisticated materials through control of nanoscale structure.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

div.div:
The synthesis and assembly of organic and inorganic nanomaterials into superstructures have been extensively studied in many research fields.
(1−5)
Colloidal inorganic nanoparticles (NPs) are an attractive material class because physicochemical properties and self-organization are tunable with changes in size,
(6,7)
shape,
(8,9)
and composition.
(10,11)
The self-assembly of NPs offers a low-cost, bottom-up approach for fabrication of materials for electronics,
(12,13)
photonics,
(14,15)
and magnetics.
(16,17)
Moreover, self-assembled NPs exhibit collective properties that are not equal to the mere sum of the properties of constituents.
(18,19)
Therefore, understanding self-assembly behavior of NPs is of great importance to reach the full potential of NP-based applications.

During the self-assembly of NPs, the packing symmetry of NPs is determined by a variety of factors including core size, solvent type, ligand length, and deformation of ligands.
(20−25)
In single-component assemblies, the NP softness parameter, λ, plays a critical role in determining the final superlattice symmetry, where λ is defined by the ratio of the extended ligand length (
L
) to core radius (
R
).
(24,26,27)
In the case of alkyl chain-coated NPs, close-packed structures (
i
.
e
., face-centered cubic (fcc) and hexagonal close-packed (hcp) symmetry) are strongly favored when λ is lower than 0.6–0.7, and otherwise non-close-packed symmetries (
e
.
g
., body-centered cubic (bcc) and body-centered tetragonal (bct)) are more favored. Interestingly, however, our group recently reported that polymer-grafted NPs show a different phase transition boundary as a function of λ than that of alkyl-chain-coated NPs. That is, polystyrene-coated Au NPs (
[email protected]
) formed fcc symmetries even with a λ of 3.0. This phenomenon led us to formulate an “effective softness” parameter by defining the “hard core” radius to include both the inorganic core and the concentrated polymer brush (CPB) regime, where interdigitation and deformability of ligands are limited. The effective softness was controlled by varying the grafting density of the polymer brush. Another potential route to control the softness of NPs is by changing the number-average molecular weight (
M
n
) of polymeric ligands. Alivisatos and Xu
et
al
. reported that the structural diversity of binary NP superlattices is enriched with polystyrene ligands of various
M
n
.
(28)
The authors proposed that this effect is due to increased deformability of polymeric ligands relative to short alkyl ligands. However, despite the documented effects of polymeric ligands on structural diversity, simple design rules that account for both
M
n
and NP core size are lacking.

Herein, we report the self-assembly behavior of
[email protected]
NPs as a function of the effective softness. A series of
[email protected]
NPs were prepared by varying core sizes from 2.9 to 9.6 nm and
M
n
of PS from 1.8 to 7.9 kg mol
–1
, while grafting density was mostly in the range of 1–2 chains nm
–2
. These NP designs yield effective softness parameter values (λ
eff
) that range from 0.03 to 5.16. First, we demonstrated the reliability of λ
eff
in conjunction with the optimal packing model (OPM) for the prediction of the effective radius of NPs. While the conventional prediction based on λ consistently underestimated the effective radius of NPs by −10% to −20%, the predictions based on λ
eff
generally agreed with the experimental data within ±9% for core radii above 5 nm. The as-prepared
[email protected]
NPs were self-assembled through a liquid–air interface assembly technique, producing large-area NP superlattices. Using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray scattering, we confirmed that the packing symmetry of
[email protected]
NPs was transformed from hcp to bct and to bcc with increasing λ
eff
. Our work suggests that the parameter λ
eff
can guide the design of NP superlattices with tunable interparticle distance and packing symmetries, which is critical for applications in magnetics, plasmonics, and electronics.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Previously, we reported the effect of grafting density (Σ) on the packing symmetry of
[email protected]
NPs. We showed that NPs assemble into a close-packed symmetry when Σ is high, even if λ (
Figure
1
a) is as large as 3, although non-close-packed symmetries (
i
.
e
., bcc) are favored when λ is high.
(29)
We attributed this phenomenon to the presence of a CPB regime around the Au surface that inhibits the ligand–ligand interactions that drive the formation of non-close-packed symmetries (
i
.
e
., bcc). The Σ-dependent softness was formulated into an “effective softness” (λ
eff
,
Figure
1
b) by including the CPB regime as a part of the hard core region, showing the fcc-to-bcc transition at λ
eff
of 0.4–0.9 for 3 nm Au NPs coated by 1.8k PS. However, since λ
eff
is a function of Σ, core radius (
R
), and ligand length (
L
), it is important to investigate the self-assembly behavior of
[email protected]
NPs with varying
R
and
L
as well as Σ to assess the universal validity of the effective softness model.

div.p:
Figure 1. Illustrations showing the concept of (a) conventional NP softness (λ) and (b) effective NP softness (λ
eff
). (c) TEM images of
[email protected]
with various core size (2.9–9.6 nm) and ligand length (
M
n
= 1.8–7.9 kg mol
–1
) and (d) corresponding histogram of the core-to-core distance of each sample. The scale bars represent 50 nm.

div.div:
In this regard, we prepared a series of
[email protected]
NPs with combinations of four different values of
R
(from 2.9 to 9.6 nm) and four different values of
M
n
of PS ligands (from 1.8 to 7.9 kg mol
–1
). For these samples, Σ ranged from 0.97 to 2.19 chains nm
–2
(
Table S1
), which were the largest values that we could obtain for each combination of
R
and
M
n
. The 2.9 and 5.3 nm Au NPs were synthesized using a previously reported method.
(30)
The 7.1 and 9.6 nm Au NPs were synthesized through a seeded growth method
(31)
using 5.3 nm Au NPs as seeds. As shown in the TEM images (
Figure S1a–d
) and the histograms of the size distribution (
Figure S1e
), as-synthesized NPs are highly monodisperse with less than 8% standard deviation in radius. The as-synthesized NPs were ligand exchanged by thiol-terminated PS (PS-SH) to prepare a large set of
[email protected]
NPs having different core sizes and
M
n
of PS ligands.
(32,33)
More detailed procedures for the synthesis of PS-SH and
[email protected]
NPs are described in the
Experimental Section
. TEM images of as-prepared
[email protected]
NPs in the monolayer are presented in
Figure
1
c. All the
[email protected]
NPs form highly uniform hexagonal packing structures due to its highest packing density in the monolayer. In addition, with the increase of the PS
M
n
and the core size, the NP core-to-core distance could be controlled from 6 nm to more than 20 nm, as shown in
Figure
1
d.
(34)
For example, in the case of
[email protected]
NPs with a 9.6 nm Au core size, the core-to-core distance increases from 11.5 ± 0.4 nm to 20.4 ± 0.5 nm. Core-to-core distance values of all the samples are summarized in
Table S1
. For convenience, we label
[email protected]
NPs as
[email protected]
where X and Y represent the core size of NPs and the
M
n
of PS ligands, respectively.

The as-prepared
[email protected]
NPs were self-assembled using a liquid–air interface assembly technique for the formation of well-ordered NP superlattices over large areas.
(35)
The self-assembled packing symmetries of the
[email protected]
NPs were analyzed using TEM images and GISAXS data as presented in
Figure
2
and
Figure
3
, respectively. Unit cell parameters of all the samples are summarized in
Table S2
. In general, the self-assembly behavior of NPs was consistent with expectations, where a close-packed symmetry (
i
.
e
., hcp) was formed when the ligand length was relatively short compared with the radius of the inorganic core, and otherwise a non-close-packed symmetry (
i
.
e
., bcc or bct) was formed. The GISAXS data for samples with hcp symmetry are consistent with an hcp lattice and inconsistent with an fcc lattice. However, to provide the closest match between the observed and predicted Bragg peak positions, the out-of-plane distance between adjacent close-packed planes was set to a larger value than typical for an hcp lattice (by approximately 15%). This may reflect a minor fcc phase or other stacking faults. The bcc and bct symmetries were always oriented with the closest-packed (110) plane parallel to the surface, as is typical in the packing of soft spheres.
(36,37)
For example, all the NPs having either 1.8k ligands (
Figure
2
a–d) or 9.6 nm core size (
Figure
2
d, h, l, and p) formed hcp symmetry. This is because hard spheres with relatively short ligands adopt a close-packed symmetry to maximize their free volume entropy,
(38,39)
while in the case of soft spheres with relatively long chain lengths (
i
.
e
., Au NPs with 7.9k ligands except for 9.6 nm Au NPs), the self-assembly is dominated by ligand packing entropy which favors a bcc symmetry.
(27,40−42)
Therefore, when we prepared smaller size Au NPs (1.9 nm) with 1.8k ligands, the
[email protected]
NPs formed a bcc symmetry due to relatively long polymer chain length compared with the core size (
Figure S2
)
.

The bcc and bct symmetries are 110-oriented, so the closest packed plane is within the plane of the film. The hcp symmetries are 0001-oriented. The scale bars represent 50 nm.

div.div:
Interestingly, the GISAXS data show the formation of bct phase in 7.1
[email protected]
and 7.1
[email protected]
with 7% and 10% stretching relative to bcc along the out-of-plane
c
-axis, respectively, which has been reported as an intermediate structure for the close-packed symmetry (
i
.
e
., fcc and hcp) to bcc transitions.
(43−45)
It is noteworthy that a similar phase transition has been also reported in the cases of DNA-coated nanocubes: specifically, a transition from simple cubic, which is the close-packed symmetry for cubes, to bct and bcc. This behavior was mainly driven by localization of DNA linkers at different facets of the nanocubes depending on the length of the DNA linkers, which changes the interactions between different facets.
(46,47)
This differs from the effects that drive symmetry transitions in the present study, as the
[email protected]
NPs were spherical and the PS ligands were expected to cover the surface of the Au NPs uniformly. Accordingly, there should be no orientational preference that drives packing of the polymer-grafted Au NPs.

Importantly, the formation of hcp symmetry in some of the
[email protected]
NPs (
Figure
2
a–d, f–h, k, l, and p), despite their very large λ values of over 0.9, is contrary to the previously known preference for the bcc symmetry of alkyl-coated NPs with similar softness parameters.
(26,27)
Such close-packed symmetries (
i
.
e
., fcc and hcp) have been both experimentally
(48)
and theoretically
(49)
demonstrated in other examples of polymer-coated NPs with relatively long chain lengths as well. This contradiction can be explained by the effective softness λ
eff
, which includes the CPB regime as a part of the hard core, and thus lowers the “softness” of the
[email protected]
NPs.
(29)
λ
eff
is calculated as follows:
(50−53)
(1)
R
c
is the critical radius for the CPB to semidilute polymer brush (SDPB) transition,
L
eff
is the stretched length of polymer chains in the SDPB regime,
(54)
and
N
SDPB
is the number of monomers per chain in the SDPB regime.
R
c
is calculated by the theoretical model to predict the CPB to SDPB crossover, proposed by Ohno
et
al
.,
(53)
as follows:
(2)
Σ is the grafting density,
R
is the core radius,
l
0
is the monomer length, and
v
is the excluded volume parameter. Since we used polystyrene ligands,
l
0
= 0.252 nm.
(51)
Σ of the samples was calculated based on thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in
Figure S3
. It is noted that the choice of
v
is important in our model.
v
is defined by
, where χ is the Flory–Huggins interaction parameter.
(52,55)
We chose
v
= 0.5 by assuming a very good solvent condition (χ = 0). Further discussion about the choice of
v
,
(56)
more detailed calculation steps, and the calculated values of
R
,
L
eff
, and λ
eff
can be found in the Supporting Information (
Tables S3 and S4
).

λ
eff
values were calculated for all the samples as summarized in
Table
1
. Before discussing the relationship between λ
eff
and the packing symmetry of NP superlattices, the validity of λ
eff
can be tested by using the optimal packing model to predict the interparticle distance as a function of λ
eff
(instead of λ) and then comparing the predictions with experimental values from GISAXS.
(27)
In our previous work, we found that OPM based on λ
eff
provides a more accurate prediction of the effective radius of polymer-grafted NPs than the OPM based on λ. As shown in
Figure
4
, when the radius values are predicted by λ
,
the slope of the fitted line is 0.87. However, when the radius values are predicted by λ
eff,
the slope of the fitted line is 1.00. These outcomes demonstrate that the OPM predictions based on λ tend to underestimate the radius, while predictions based on λ
eff
are more reliable because they are not biased toward overestimation or underestimation. Specifically, while most of the λ-based OPM consistently underestimated the effective radius of NPs by −20% to −10%, the λ
eff
-based prediction showed good agreement with the experimental values within ±9% for the inorganic core radii above 5 nm. The same conclusion is reached by comparing the mean absolute errors (MAEs) of each model, as shown in
Figure S4
, which are 16.5 ± 7.0% and 6.7 ± 5.1% for λ- and λ
eff
-based predictions, respectively. All the predicted radii values are summarized in
Table S4
, and the detailed calculation method can be found in the
Supporting Information
.

Table 1. Effective Softness (λ
eff
) Values of the NPs Used in This Study
a

div.p:
Red, orange, and blue colors represent hcp, bct, and bcc symmetries, respectively. The unit of Σ is chains nm
–2
.

Figure 4. Experimental effective radii of NPs (from GISAXS) compared with OPM predictions using (a) λ and (b) λ
eff
as the softness parameter. The dashed black line shows the one-to-one matched line for the measured radius and predicted radius.

div.div:
While λ
eff
captures essential attributes of polymer brush physics that improve predictions of the effective size of NPs, there are a few limitations with this approach. First, the effective softness model does not account for ligand–ligand overlap in the CPB regime. As a result, both ligand stretching and the interparticle distance are overestimated for samples where most or all of the brush thickness is in the CPB regime. Second, as can be seen in
Table S4
, the OPM predictions using either λ or λ
eff
show increasing deviations with experiments as NP core sizes are reduced (
i
.
e
., 1.9 and 2.9 nm), although these deviations are smaller when λ
eff
is employed instead of λ. This seems to be an intrinsic problem with the OPM when applied to polymer-grafted NPs, as a similar underestimation of the effective size was found in previous works that also applied the OPM to the alkyl-chain-coated NPs with large λ (>2).
(57,58)
It is also important to note that predictions are sensitive to the model parameters, and the values for these parameters are specified based on prior literature rather than optimized to reduce the error. As an example, the predicted thickness of the CPB regime is sensitive to the excluded volume parameter
v
, and the value of
v
= 0.5 was selected based on a prior work.
(59)
Nevertheless, the data in
Figure
4
demonstrate that the OPM coupled with the effective softness parameter offers a powerful approach to predict the effective size (or interparticle distance) of polymer-coated NPs.

As found in
Table
1
and
Figure
5
, the packing symmetry of
[email protected]
NPs is transformed from hcp to bct and to bcc as λ
eff
is increased. For example, 5.3 nm
[email protected]
NPs formed hcp symmetry at λ
eff
of 0.03 and 0.98 and bcc at 1.95 and 2.28. Also, since λ
eff
increases as Σ decreases, we can modulate the packing symmetry by varying Σ. Indeed, by feeding a lower amount of PS ligands during the ligand exchange process,
(29)
we prepared 5.3
[email protected]
with relatively lower Σ (0.96 chains nm
–1
) to obtain a λ
eff
of 1.59 between 0.98 and 1.95, and the NPs assembled into bct symmetry as observed in GISAXS data (
Figure S5a
). Such structural transitions depending on Σ were demonstrated in 7.1
[email protected]
and 9.6
[email protected]
by reducing Σ to 1.04 and 0.65 chains nm
–2
, respectively. These changes induced a bct to bcc transition in 7.1
[email protected]
and an hcp to bct transition in 9.6
[email protected]
(
Figure S5b and c
). The decrease of Σ drives these structural transitions by making the organic shell around the NP surface softer, allowing stronger interdigitation between the ligands and thereby forming non-close-packed symmetries.
(29)
It is important to note that we can independently tune the interparticle distance and the packing symmetry by varying
M
n
and Σ at the same time. That is, for example, both 9.6
[email protected]
with a Σ of 1.03 chains nm
–2
and 9.6
[email protected]
with a Σ of 0.65 chains nm
–2
have almost identical interparticle distances of ∼16 nm (
Table S1
) but different packing symmetries of hcp and bct, respectively, which cannot be achieved by changing either
M
n
or Σ alone. This independent tuning of the interparticle distance and packing symmetry can enable investigations that aim to isolate the effects of packing symmetry on material properties. For instance, since each packing symmetry has a different coordination number of 12, 10, and 8 for hcp, bct, and bcc, respectively, different degrees of interparticle interactions are expected, which can be critical in various inorganic NP-based applications.
(60−63)

div.p:
Figure 5. Phase diagram of NP superlattices as a function of diameter of the inorganic core (2
R
) and λ
eff
. The packing symmetry was transformed from hcp (red square) to bct (orange triangle) and bcc (blue circle). The data are combined with previously reported data from ref
(30)
, which are the filled red squares (hcp) and blue circles (bcc).

div.div:
Interestingly, 9.6
[email protected]
with a Σ of 0.65 chain nm
–2
showed a bct symmetry despite its very large λ
eff
of 2.31. This suggests that the λ
eff
value for the close-packed to non-close-packed symmetry transition is varied according to the core size of NPs, and the value for the transition increases as the size of the NP core increases. For instance, the packing symmetry of the
[email protected]
NPs with a 3.1 nm core size showed an hcp to bcc transition at λ
eff
between 0.43 and 0.87,
(29)
whereas NPs with a 5.3 nm core size showed an hcp to bcc transition at λ
eff
between 0.98 and 1.95 with formation of bct at 1.59. Moreover, as mentioned above, 9.6 nm Au NPs showed only hcp symmetry up to a λ
eff
of 1.27, and bct symmetry was formed even at a λ
eff
of 2.31, where formation of bcc is strongly favored in all the other core sizes of Au NPs. This size-dependent phase behavior of
[email protected]
NPs originates from the underestimation of the effective softness of small-sized NPs. As we described in the
Supporting Information
, the effective Σ (Σ
eff
) at
R
c
is constant regardless of
R
or
R
c
. Since the ligands on smaller
R
c
experience less steric hindrance, the effective softness is underestimated for small-sized NPs compared with relatively large NPs. Thus, the phase transition from hcp to bcc was observed at lower λ
eff
, leading to the size-dependent phase behavior of the NPs in
Figure
5
.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, we describe the effects of particle softness and size on packing symmetries of PS-grafted Au NPs. The effective softness (λ
eff
) of NPs was varied from 0.03 to 5.16 by changing both the
M
n
of PS ligands and the core size of Au NPs. While the λ-based OPM prediction of the effective radius (
i
.
e
., half of the interparticle distance) consistently underestimated the effective radius by −10 to −20%, the λ
eff
-based OPM prediction of the effective radius was within ±9% for inorganic core radii over 5 nm. TEM and GISAXS analyses revealed that the packing symmetry of
[email protected]
NPs is strongly dependent on λ
eff
, with symmetry transitions from hcp to bct and to bcc as λ
eff
was increased. This outcome was used to map out a phase diagram for predictable phase behavior of
[email protected]
NPs. Through simultaneous control of inorganic core size, Σ, and
M
n
of ligands, we could achieve different packing symmetries of Au NPs with the same core size and the same interparticle distance, which is difficult to realize by changing a single parameter. This effective softness model provides a simple but reliable parameter that can predict the interparticle distance and self-assembly behavior, which is critical for the rational design of functional nanostructured materials.

div.div:
HAuCl
4
·3H
2
O (99%), oleylamine (OAm, technical grade), tetralin (technical grade),
tert
-butylamine-borane complex (TBAB), 1-octadecene (90%), diethylene glycol (99%), ethylene sulfide (98%), styrene (99%), anhydrous cyclohexane, anhydrous methanol, and
sec
-butyllithium solution (
sec
-BuLi, 1.6 M in hexane) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Ethylene sulfide and styrene were dried using calcium hydride and then distilled at low pressure. Distilled ethylene sulfide and styrene as well as cyclohexane were degassed for three cycles of freeze–pump–thaw. Other chemicals were used as received.

For the synthesis of 2.9 nm Au NPs, an orange-colored mixture of HAuCl
4
·3H
2
O (100 mg), tetralin (10 mL), and OAm (10 mL) was prepared in air at 20 °C and stirred using a magnetic bar under N
2
for 10 min. A solution containing 0.5 mmol of TBAB, tetralin (1 mL), and OAm (1 mL) was sonicated until TBAB was completely dissolved, and the solution was injected into the precursor solution to reduce the Au precursor. As soon as the TBAB solution was injected, the color of the solution turned into deep purple, indicating the reduction of the Au precursor. After 1 h, 20 mL of hexane was added into the reaction mixture and Au NPs were precipitated by adding 60 mL of ethanol. The Au NPs were collected by centrifugation (8000 rpm, 2 min) and redispersed in THF. For the synthesis of 5.3 nm Au NPs, we reduced the reaction temperature to ∼2 °C while keeping other conditions the same. For the synthesis of 7.1 and 9.6 nm Au NPs, the seeded growth technique was employed using 5.3 nm Au NPs as seeds. Typically, a gold precursor solution was prepared by dissolving 120 mg of HAuCl
4
·3H
2
O in 3 mL of OLAM and 3 mL of 1-octadecene. The precursor solution was mixed in a 50 mL flask with the calculated amount of Au NPs depending on the target size. Under a N
2
atmosphere and stirring, the reaction mixture was heated to 80 °C. After 2 h, the reaction mixture was cooled rapidly using a water bath and then purified using the same step used for the synthesis of 2.9 nm Au NPs. No further size-selective purification step was required.

PS-SH was synthesized using living anionic polymerization as previously reported.
(64)
A 250 mL amount of cyclohexane in a 1000 mL three-neck round-bottomed flask was heated to 35 °C. A 10 mL amount of
sec
-BuLi was added to the solution for initiating polymerization. Then, 15 g of styrene monomer was poured into the solution. After 8 h, 0.392 mL of ethylene sulfide was injected into the reaction mixture. After the injection, the solution color gradually changed from red to orange. When the color of the solution stopped changing, 5 mL of anhydrous methanol was added to terminate the reaction. PS-SH was precipitated by adding excess methanol and obtained as a white powder. The number-average molecular weight (
M
n
) and dispersity (
Đ
) were 1.8 kg mol
–1
and 1.1, respectively, which were measured by size exclusion chromatography (SEC) (Waters 2414). The SEC is calibrated by PS standards with THF. To obtain different
M
n
’s of PS-SH, the amount of
sec
-BuLi was changed to 5, 3.3, and 2.5 mL, which yielded
M
n
’s of 4.3, 6.4, and 7.9 kg mol
–1
, respectively. Their
Đ
values were lower than 1.1.

Au NPs grafted with PS-SH were prepared by a simple ligand exchange process. For the ligand exchange, as-synthesized Au NPs were dispersed in THF to a concentration of 5 mg mL
–1
. A PS-SH solution was prepared separately with a polymer concentration of 2.5 mM in THF. The as-synthesized Au NP solution and PS-SH solution were mixed at a 1:1 volume ratio and stirred for 12 h at room temperature. The
[email protected]
NPs were precipitated by adding hexane and centrifuged at 8000 rpm for 10 min. The supernatant was discarded, and then the precipitated
[email protected]
NPs were redispersed in toluene. This procedure was repeated at least five to six times to remove unbound PS-SH.

For the formation of
[email protected]
superlattices,
[email protected]
NP of 5 mg mL
–1
in toluene was used. A 15 μL amount of the
[email protected]
solution was gently dropped on a diethylene glycol (DEG) surface in a homemade Teflon well (1.5 × 1.5 × 1.5 cm
3
). The well was quickly covered by a slide glass, and toluene was slowly evaporated at least for 12 h. A pink-purple solid film was formed on top of the DEG surface. A substrate (
i
.
e
., TEM grid or silicon wafer) was placed under the film using tweezers and then gently lifted to transfer the film to the substrate. Then, the film was dried under vacuum overnight to remove residual DEG. Samples on silicon wafers and TEM grids were prepared for GISAXS measurements and TEM analysis, respectively.

TEM characterization was performed using a JEM-3011 HR microscope operating at 300 kV. GISAXS measurements were performed on beamline 9A in the Pohang Acceleratory Laboratory (South Korea). The samples were irradiated by an 11.055 keV (λ = 0.112 nm) X-ray beam with a sample-to-detector distance of 2.5 m. The off-specular scattering was recorded using a MAR-CCD area detector (1920 × 1920 pixels, 0.0886 nm pixel size). The incidence angle of the X-ray beam was changed in the range of 0.15–0.25° for better accuracy of symmetry assignment. Procedures for GISAXS data analysis are summarized in the
Supporting Information
.

Au nanocrystals, each encapsulated by a monolayer of alkyl thiol mols., were cast from a colloidal soln. onto a flat substrate to form a close-packed cluster monolayer. Org. interconnects (aryl dithiols or aryl diisonitriles) displaced the alkyl thiol mols. and covalently linked adjacent clusters in the monolayer to form a two-dimensional superlattice of metal quantum dots coupled by uniform tunnel junctions. Au clusters, deposited on a SiO2 substrate in the gap between two Au contacts and linked by an aryl di-isonitrile [1,4-di(4-isocyanophenylethynyl)-2-ethylbenene], exhibited nonlinear Coulomb charging behavior.

Drying-mediated self-assembly of nanoparticles
Rabani, Eran; Reichman, David R.; Geissler, Phillip L.; Brus, Louis E.
Nature (London, United Kingdom)
(

Systems far from equil. can exhibit complex transitory structures, even when equil. fluctuations are mundane. A dramatic example of this phenomenon has recently been demonstrated for thin-film solns. of passivated nanocrystals during the irreversible evapn. of the solvent. The relatively weak attractions between nanocrystals, which are efficiently screened in soln., become manifest as the solvent evaps., initiating assembly of intricate, slowly evolving structures. Although certain aspects of this aggregation process can be explained using thermodn. arguments alone, it is in principle a non-equil. process. A representation of this process as arising from the phase sepn. between a dense nanocrystal liq.' and dil. nanocrystal vapor' captures some of the behavior obsd. in expts., but neglects entirely the role of solvent fluctuations, which can be considerable on the nanometer length scale. Here we present a coarse-grained model of nanoparticle self-assembly that explicitly includes the dynamics of the evapg. solvent. Simulations using this model not only account for all obsd. spatial and temporal patterns, but also predict network structures that have yet to be explored. Two distinct mechanisms of ordering emerge, corresponding to the homogeneous and heterogeneous limits of evapn. dynamics. Our calcns. show how different choices of solvent, nanoparticle size (and identity) and thermodn. state give rise to the various morphologies of the final structures. The resulting guide for designing statistically patterned arrays of nanoparticles suggests the possibility of fabricating spontaneously organized nanoscale devices.

Controlling the Self-Assembly Structure of Magnetic Nanoparticles and Amphiphilic Block-Copolymers: From Micelles to Vesicles
Hickey, Robert J.; Haynes, Alyssa S.; Kikkawa, James M.; Park, So-Jung
Journal of the American Chemical Society

We report how to control the self-assembly of magnetic nanoparticles and a prototypical amphiphilic block-copolymer composed of poly(acrylic acid) and polystyrene (PAA-b-PS). Three distinct structures were obtained by controlling the solvent-nanoparticle and polymer-nanoparticle interactions: (1) polymersomes densely packed with nanoparticles (magneto-polymersomes), (2) core-shell type polymer assemblies where nanoparticles are radially arranged at the interface between the polymer core and the shell (magneto-core shell), and (3) polymer micelles where nanoparticles are homogeneously incorporated (magneto-micelles). Importantly, we show that the incorporation of nanoparticles drastically affects the self-assembly structure of block-copolymers by modifying the relative vol. ratio between the hydrophobic block and the hydrophilic block. As a consequence, the self-assembly of micelle-forming block-copolymers typically produces magneto-polymersomes instead of magneto-micelles. On the other hand, vesicle-forming polymers tend to form magneto-micelles due to the solubilization of nanoparticles in polymer assemblies. The nanoparticle-polymer interaction also controls the nanoparticle arrangement in the polymer matrix. In N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) where PS is not well-solvated, nanoparticles segregate from PS and form unique radial assemblies. In THF, which is a good solvent for both nanoparticles and PS, nanoparticles are homogeneously distributed in the polymer matrix. Furthermore, we demonstrated that the morphol. of nanoparticle-encapsulating polymer assemblies significantly affects their magnetic relaxation properties, emphasizing the importance of the self-assembly structure and nanoparticle arrangement as well as the size of the assemblies.

Herein, we report a simple fabrication of hybrid nanowires (NWs) composed of a p-type conjugated polymer (CP) and n-type inorg. quantum dots (QDs) by exploiting the crystn.-driven soln. assembly of poly(3-hexylthiophene)-b-poly(2-vinylpyridine) (P3HT-b-P2VP) rod-coil amphiphiles. The visualization of the crystn.-driven growth evolution of hybrid NWs through systematic transmission electron microscopy expts. showed that discrete dimeric CdSe QDs bridged by P3HT-b-P2VP polymers were generated during the initial state of crystn. These, in turn, assemble into elongated fibrils, forming the coaxial P3HT-b-P2VP/QDs hybrid NWs. In particular, the location of the QD arrays within the single strand of P3HT-b-P2VP can be controlled precisely by manipulating the regioregularity (RR) values of P3HT block and the relative lengths of P2VP block. The degree of coaxiality of the QD arrays was shown to depend on the coplanarity of the thiophene rings of P3HT block, which can be controlled by the RR value of P3HT block. In addn., the location of QDs could be regulated at the specific-local site of P3HT-b-P2VP NW according to the surface characteristics of QDs. As an example, the comparison of two different QDs coated with hydrophobic alkyl-terminated and hydroxyl-terminated mols., resp., is used to elucidate the effect of the surface properties of QDs on their nanolocation in the NW.

Polymer nanocomposite films contg. gold nanorods (AuNRs) and poly(2-vinyl pyridine) (P2VP) were studied for their structure-optical property relation. Using TEM, the assembly of AuNRs (7.9 nm × 28.4 nm) grafted with a P2VP brush in P2VP films is examd. as a function of the AuNR vol. fraction OAuNRs and film thickness h. For h ∼ 40 nm, AuNRs are confined to align parallel to the film and uniformly dispersed at low OAuNRs. Upon increasing OAuNRs, nanorods form discrete aggregates contg. mainly side-by-side arrays due to depletion-attraction forces. For OAuNRs = 2.7%, AuNRs assemble into a 2-dimensional network where the discrete aggregates are connected by end-to-end linked nanorods. As OAuNRs further increases, the polymer-rich regions of the network fill in with nanorods and rod overlap is obsd. Monte Carlo simulations capture the exptl. obsd. morphologies. The effect of film thickness is studied at OAuNRs = 2.7%, where thicker films (40 and 70 nm) show a dense array of percolated nanorods and thinner films (20 nm) exhibit mainly isolated nanorods. Using Rutherford backscattering spectrometry (RBS), the AuNRs segregate near the substrate during spin-casting. Optically, the longitudinal surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) peaks are correlated with the local orientation of the AuNRs, where side-by-side and end-to-end alignments induce blue and red shifts, resp. The LSPR undergoes a red shift up to 51 nm as OAuNRs increases from 1.6 to 2.7%. The optical properties of polymer nanocomposite films contg. gold nanorods can be fine-tuned by changing OAuNRs and h. These results are broadly applicable and provide guidelines for dispersing other functional nanoparticles, such as quantum dots and carbon nanotubes.

Ultra-large-scale syntheses of monodisperse nanocrystals
Park, Jongnam; An, Kwangjin; Hwang, Yosun; Park, Je-Geun; Noh, Han-Jin; Kim, Jae-Young; Park, Jae-Hoon; Hwang, Nong-Moon; Hyeon, Taeghwan

.
(
Nature Publishing Group

The development of nanocrystals has been intensively pursued, not only for their fundamental scientific interest, but also for many technol. applications. The synthesis of monodisperse nanocrystals (size variation <5%) is of key importance, because the properties of these nanocrystals depend strongly on their dimensions. For example, the color sharpness of semiconductor nanocrystal-based optical devices is strongly dependent on the uniformity of the nanocrystals, and monodisperse magnetic nanocrystals are crit. for the next-generation multiterabit magnetic storage media. For these monodisperse nanocrystals to be used, an economical mass prodn. method needs to be developed. Unfortunately, however, in most syntheses reported so far, only subgram quantities of monodisperse nanocrystals were produced. Uniform-sized nanocrystals of CdSe and Au have been produced using colloidal chem. synthetic procedures. In addn., monodisperse magnetic nanocrystals such as Fe, Co, γ-Fe2O3, and Fe3O4 have been synthesized by using various synthetic methods. Here, we report on the ultralarge-scale synthesis of monodisperse nanocrystals using inexpensive and nontoxic metal salts as reactants. We were able to synthesize as much as 40 g of monodisperse nanocrystals in a single reaction, without a size sorting process. Moreover, the particle size could be controlled simply by varying the exptl. conditions. The current synthetic procedure is very general and nanocrystals of many transition metal oxides were successfully synthesized using a very similar procedure.

Ku, Kang Hee; Shin, Jae Man; Kim, Minsoo P.; Lee, Chun-Ho; Seo, Min-Kyo; Yi, Gi-Ra; Jang, Se Gyu; Kim, Bumjoon J.

The tuning of interfacial properties at selective and desired locations on the particles is of great importance to create the novel structured particles by breaking the symmetry of their surface property. Herein, a dramatic transition of both the external shape and internal morphol. of the particles of polystyrene-b-poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P4VP) was induced by precise positioning of size-controlled Au nanoparticle surfactants (Au NPs). The size-dependent assembly of the Au NPs was localized preferentially at the interface between the P4VP domain at the particle surface and the surrounding water, which generated a balanced interfacial interaction between two different PS/P4VP domains of the BCP particles and water, producing unique convex lens-shaped BCP particles. In addn., the neutralized interfacial interaction, in combination with the directionality of the solvent-induced ordering of the BCP domains from the interface of the particle/water, generated defect-free, vertically ordered porous channels within the particles. The mechanism for the formation of these novel nanostructures was investigated systemically by varying the size and the vol. fraction of the Au NPs. Furthermore, these convex lens-shaped particles with highly ordered channels can be used as a microlens, in which the light can be concd. toward the focal point with enhanced near-field signals. And, these particles can possess addnl. optical properties such as unique distribution of light scattering as a result of the well-ordered Au cylinders that filled into the channels, which hold great promise for use in optical, biol.-sensing, and imaging applications.

Expts. in a continuous flow reactor with 1-propanol solvent, at 120 to 160°C and 33 bar H2, demonstrated that reaction is sequential on both Pt and PtCo alloys, with 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) formed as an intermediate product. However, the reaction of DMF is greatly suppressed on the alloys, such that a Pt3Co2 catalyst achieved DMF yields as high as 98%. XRD and XAS data indicate that the Pt3Co2 catalyst consists of a Pt-rich core and a Co oxide surface monolayer whose structure differs substantially from that of bulk Co oxide. We demonstrate that control over metal nanoparticle size and compn., along with operating conditions, is crucial to achieving good performance and stability. Implications of this mechanism for other reactions and catalysts are discussed.

Doping is a process in which at. impurities are intentionally added to a host material to modify its properties. It has had a revolutionary impact in altering or introducing electronic, magnetic, luminescent, and catalytic properties for several applications, for example in semiconductors. The authors explore and demonstrate the extension of the concept of substitutional at. doping to nanometer-scale crystal doping, in which one nanocrystal was used to replace another to form doped self-assembled superlattices. Towards this goal, Au nanocrystals act as substitutional dopants in superlattices of Cd selenide or lead selenide nanocrystals when the size of the Au nanocrystal is very close to that of the host. The Au nanocrystals occupy random positions in the superlattice and their d. is readily and widely controllable, analogous to the case of at. doping, but here through nanocrystal self-assembly. Also the electronic properties of the superlattices are highly tunable and strongly affected by the presence and d. of the Au nanocrystal dopants. The cond. of lead selenide films, for example, can be manipulated over at least six orders of magnitude by the addn. of Au nanocrystals and is explained by a percolation model. As this process relies on the self-assembly of uniform nanocrystals, it can be generally applied to assemble a wide variety of nanocrystal-doped structures for electronic, optical, magnetic, and catalytic materials.

The integration of colloidal nanocrystals with polymers adds optoelectronic functionalities to flexible and mech. robust org. films. In particular, self-assembled structures of nanocrystals in polymers can act as functional components enhancing, for instance, transport or optical properties of the hybrid material. This study presents Cu2Te hexagonal nanodisks that assemble into ribbons with a face-to-face configuration in poly(3-hexylthiophene-2,5-diyl) through a controlled solvent evapn. process. The ribbons form weaving patterns that create 3-dimensional networks fully embedded in the thin polymer film at high nanodisk concn. The photoresponse of these composite films measured in a layered vertical geometry demonstrates increased photocurrent with increasing nanocrystal loading. This study attributes this behavior to the presence of networks of Cu2Te nanodisks that form a bulk heterojunction with the semiconducting polymer, which improves exciton dissocn. and the overall photoelec. response.

Quantum dot superlattices offer prospects for new generations of semiconductor devices. One possible recently suggested application is in tandem solar cells based entirely on silicon, using confinement in the quantum dot to control the cell band gap. The effective mass approach was used to calc. the conduction band structure of a three-dimensional silicon quantum dot superlattice with the dots embedded in a matrix of silicon dioxide, silicon nitride, or silicon carbide. The quantum dot superlattice is modeled as a regularly spaced array of equally sized cubic dots in the resp. matrix. Incorporating the effect of silicon anisotropic effective mass is shown to reduce both the degeneracies of the isotropic solns. and the energy sepn. between states. Electron densities of state and mobilities are derived from the band structure data. Theor. results for the effect of dot size, interdot distance, and matrix material have been obtained. These results clarify the required design features of silicon quantum dot superlattices for the proposed all-silicon tandem solar cells.

The authors report a size-dependent change in the morphol. of superlattices self-assembled from monodisperse colloidal PbS nanocrystals. Superlattices of large (>7 nm) PbS nanocrystals showed a strong tendency to form multiply twinned face-centered cubic superlattices with decahedral and icosahedral symmetry, exhibiting crystallog. forbidden five-fold symmetry elements. On the other hand, superlattices of small (<4 nm) PbS nanocrystals exhibited no twinning. To explain such a dramatic difference in the twinning probability, the authors showed that twinning energy in a nanocrystal superlattice is strongly size-dependent. In addn., the interparticle potentials acting during the self-assembly process are "softer" in the case of larger PbS nanocrystals, thus favoring the formation of multiply twinned superlattices. The authors work introduces a new class of materials exhibiting multiple twinning, while offering flexibility in designing interparticle potentials.

Understanding self-assembly is a crit. step toward controlling structure at the nanometer length scale. Furthermore, small changes in nanoscale morphol. can have large impacts on the performance of nanomaterial devices. In this work, we exptl. explore how the phys. properties of lead sulfide (PbS) nanocrystals, such as the surface ligands and core size dispersity, affect the ability of these nanocrystals to self-assemble. We quantified the self-assembly quality by monitoring grain size and the percentage of nanocrystals with coherent alignment of their at. planes. We found that the ensemble size dispersity plays a large role in superlattice formation and that even small improvements in size distribution led to shorter neighbor-to-neighbor distances in superlattices (more efficient packing), larger grain sizes, and increased nanocrystal alignment. Addnl., the ligand coverage on nanocrystal surfaces had a significant influence on the self-assembly, and excess pptn. steps were highly detrimental to the formation of ordered solids. We show that surface ligand length is a more flexible parameter and that high-quality superlattices can still be achieved with compact surface ligands, so long as the nanocrystal size dispersity and ligand coverage are sufficient. Lastly, we investigated several different colloidal solvents, finding toluene to provide the best ordering, and show that nanocrystal self-assembly is largely unhindered by nanocrystal age. Overall, these results guide our understanding of the underlying factors influencing nanocrystal self-assembly and provide strategies for forming well-engineered superlattices.

The surface chem. in colloidal nanocrystals on the final cryst. structure of binary superlattices produced by self-assembly of two sets of nanocrystals is hereby demonstrated. By mixing nanocrystals having two different sizes and the same coating agent, oleylamine (OAM), the binary nanocrystal superlattices that are produced, such as NaCl, AlB2, NaZn13, and MgZn2, are well in agreement with the cryst. structures predicted by the hard-sphere model, their formation being purely driven by entropic forces. By opposition, when large and small nanocrystals are coated with two different ligands [OAM and dodecanethiol (DDT), resp.] while keeping all other exptl. conditions unchanged, the final binary structures markedly change and various structures with lower packing densities, such as Cu3Au, CaB6, and quasicrystals, are obsd. This effect of the nanocrystals' coating agents could also be extended to other binary systems, such as Ag-Au and CoFe2O4-Ag supracryst. binary lattices. In order to understand this effect, a mechanism based on ligand exchange process is proposed. Ligand exchange mechanism is believed to affect the thermodn. in the formation of binary systems composed of two sets of nanocrystals with different sizes and bearing two different coating agents. Hence, the formation of binary superlattices with lower packing densities may be favored kinetically because the required energetic penalty is smaller than that of a denser structure.

The authors demonstrate that the crystal structures of the nanocrystal superlattices made of 2.2 nm Ag nanocrystals can be controlled by using different carrier solvents. Specifically, the superlattice structures are tuned from body-centered cubic (bcc.) to face-centered cubic (fcc.) when varying solvents from hexane to tetrachloroethylene (TCE). Furthermore, by simultaneously annealing these two samples at different temps., bcc. structures originating from hexane solns. are dominated by a simple coalescence mechanism, while the fcc. structure stemming from TCE solns. undergoes an Ostwald ripening process that can produce a variety of binary nanocrystal superlattices such as NaCl, AlB2, NaZn13, and MgZn2, the formation of those structures being well explained by a pure entropy driven process. This is believed to be due to variations in the ligand coverage ratio of the nanocrystals in different solvents that are changing the superlattice structures' stability. Those findings provide insights into the solvent-mediated nanocrystal superlattices and the Ostwald ripening process in nanocrystal superlattices.

This work analyzes the role of hydrocarbon ligands in the self-assembly of nanocrystal (NC) superlattices. Typical NCs, composed of an inorg. core of radius R and a layer of capping ligands with length L, can be described as soft spheres with softness parameter L/R. Using particle tracking measurements of TEM images, close-packed NCs, like their hard-sphere counterparts, fill space at ∼74% d. independent of softness. The authors uncover deformability of the ligand capping layer that leads to variable effective NC size in response to the coordination environment. This effect plays an important role in the packing of particles in binary nanocrystal superlattices (BNSLs). Measurements on BNSLs composed of NCs of varying softness in several coordination geometries indicate that NCs deform to produce dense BNSLs that would otherwise be low-d. arrangements if the particles remained spherical. Consequently, rationalizing the mixing of 2 NC species during BNSL self-assembly need not employ complex energetic interactions. The authors summarize the anal. in a set of packing rules. These findings contribute to a general understanding of entropic effects during crystn. of deformable objects (e.g., nanoparticles, micelles, globular proteins) that can adapt their shape to the local coordination environment.

Systems of spherical nanoparticles with capping ligands have been shown to self-assemble into beautiful superlattices of fascinating structure and complexity. The model quant. predicts the structure of super-lattices where capping ligands are hydrocarbon chains in excellent agreement with exptl. results, explains the appearance of low packing fraction lattices as equil., why certain similar structures are more stable (bccAB6vs. CaB6, AuCu vs. CsCl, etc.) and many other exptl. observations.

A conceptually unique approach was developed to study the interparticle interactions between organized alkanethiol-capped Ag nanocrystals. Dense nanocrystal fluids were formed by evapg. the solvent from a "size-polydisperse" (σ⪆±12%) nanocrystal dispersion on a substrate. The sample polydispersity prevented the disorder-order phase transition (i.e., superlattice formation) from occurring. Small-angle x-ray scattering was then used to measure the static structure factors S(q), of these disordered nanocrystal films as a function of the ratio (L)/R between the capping ligand chain length to the core nanocrystal radius. The pair-distribution and direct correlation functions were then calcd. from Fourier transformations of S(q). This enabled the use of the hypernetted chain approxn. to calc. the pair interparticle potential u(r). The 6-12 Lennard-Jones potential provided reasonable fits to all exptl. detd. values of u(r), indicating the predominance of relatively short-range repulsion between nanocrystals. Monodisperse dodecanethiol- and octanethiol-capped silver nanocrystals were then condensed into ordered arrays. Face-centered-cubic packing was favored for (L)/R<0.60, and bcc. packing was favored when (L)/R>0.60. Lower-symmetry body-centered-tetragonal packing was obsd. for octanethiol-capped Ag nanocrystals with 〈L〉/R>0.66. A simple model employing the exptl. detd. values for u(r), predicts that the fcc.→bcc. superlattice phase transition occurs when (L)/R⪆0.65.

Small is different: energetic, structural, thermal, and mechanical properties of passivated nanocluster assemblies
Landman Uzi; Luedtke W D

We explore, with the use of extensive molecular dynamics simulations, several principal issues pertaining to the energetics of formation of superlattices made through the assembly of passivated nanoclusters, the interactions that underlie the cohesion of such superlattices, and the unique mechanical, thermal and structural properties that they exhibit. Our investigations focus on assemblies made of crystalline gold nanoclusters of variable sizes, passivated by monolayers of alkylthiol molecules. An analytic optimal packing model that correlates in a unified manner several structural characteristics of three-dimensional superlattice assemblies is developed. The model successfully organizes and systematizes a large amount of experimental and simulation data, and it predicts the phase-boundary between different superlattice structural motifs that evolve as a function of the ratio between the chain-length of the extended passivating molecules and the radius of the underlying gold nanocluster. The entropic contribution to the formation free energy of the superlattice assembly is found to be large and of similar magnitude as the potential energy component of the free energy. The major contribution to the cohesive potential energy of the superlattice is shown to originate from van der Waals interactions between molecules that passivate neighboring nanoclusters. The unique mechanical, thermal, thermomechanical, and thermostructural properties of passivated nanocluster assemblies, are discussed.

Multicomponent nanocrystal superlattices represent an interesting class of material that derives emergent properties from mesoscale structure, yet their programmability can be limited by the alkyl-chain-based ligands decorating the surfaces of the constituent nanocrystals. Polymeric ligands offer distinct advantages, as they allow for more precise tuning of the effective size and 'interaction softness' through changes to the polymer's mol. wt., chem. nature, architecture, persistence length and surrounding solvent. Here we show the formation of 10 different binary nanocrystal superlattices (BNSLs) with both two- and three-dimensional order through independent adjustment of the core size of spherical nanocrystals and the mol. wt. of densely grafted polystyrene ligands. These polymer-brush-based ligands introduce new energetic contributions to the interparticle potential that stabilizes various BNSL phases across a range of length scales and interparticle spacings. Our study opens the door for nanocrystals to become modular elements in the design of functional particle brush solids with controlled nanoscale interfaces and mesostructures.

Nanocrystal (NC) solids are an exciting class of materials, whose phys. properties are tunable by choice of the NCs as well as the strength of the interparticle coupling. One can consider these NCs as "artificial atoms" in analogy to the formation of condensed matter from atoms. Akin to at. doping, the doping of a semiconducting NC solid with impurity NCs can drastically alter its electronic properties. A high degree of complexity is possible in these artificial structures by adjusting the size, shape, and compn. of the building blocks, which enables "designer" materials with targeted properties. Here, we present the doping of the PbSe NC solids with a series of AuxAg1-x alloy nanoparticles (NPs). A combination of temp.-dependent elec. conductance and Seebeck coeff. measurements and room-temp. Hall effect measurements demonstrates that the incorporation of metal NPs both modifies the charge carrier d. of the NC solids and introduces energy barriers for charge transport. These studies point to charge carrier injection from the metal NPs into the PbSe NC matrix. The charge carrier d. and charge transport dynamics in the doped NC solids are adjustable in a wide range by employing the AuxAg1-x NP with different Au:Ag ratio as dopants. This doping strategy could be of great interest for thermoelec. applications taking advantage of the energy filtering effect introduced by the metal NPs.

Thiolate-protected gold surfaces and interfaces, relevant for self-assembled monolayers of organic molecules on gold, for passivated gold nanoclusters and for molecule-gold junctions, are archetypal systems in various fields of current nanoscience research, materials science, inorganic chemistry and surface science. Understanding this interface at the nanometre scale is essential for a wide range of potential applications for site-specific bioconjugate labelling and sensing, drug delivery and medical therapy, functionalization of gold surfaces for sensing, molecular recognition and molecular electronics, and gold nanoparticle catalysis. During the past five years, considerable experimental and theoretical advances have furthered our understanding of the molecular structure of the gold-sulfur interface in these systems. This Review discusses the recent progress from the viewpoint of theory and computations, with connections to relevant experiments.

A simple strategy to tailor the surface of nanoparticles for their specific adsorption to and localization at block copolymer interfaces was explored. Gold nanoparticles coated by a mixt. of low mol. wt. thiol end-functional polystyrene (PS-SH) (Mn=1.5 and 3.4 kg/mol) and poly(2-vinylpyridine) homopolymers (P2VP-SH) (Mn=1.5 and 3.0 kg/mol) were incorporated into a lamellar poly(styrene-b-2-vinylpyridine) diblock copolymer (PS-b-P2VP) (Mn=196 kg/mol). A library of nanoparticles with varying PS and P2VP surface compns. (FPS) and high polymer ligand areal chain densities was synthesized. The location of the nanoparticles in the PS-b-P2VP block copolymer was detd. by TEM. Sharp transitions in particle location from the PS domain to the PS/P2VP interface, and subsequently to the P2VP domain, were obsd. at FPS=0.9 and 0.1, resp. This extremely wide window of FPS values where the polymer-coated gold nanoparticles adsorb to the interface suggests a redistribution of PS and P2VP polymers on the Au surface, inducing the formation of amphiphilic nanoparticles at the PS/P2VP interface. In a second and synthetically more challenging approach, gold nanoparticles were covered with a thiol terminated random copolymer of styrene and 2-vinylpyridine synthesized by RAFT polymn. Two different random copolymers were considered, where the mol. wt. was fixed at 3.5 kg/mol and the relative incorporation of styrene and 2-vinylpyridine repeat units varied (FPS = 0.52 and 0.40). The areal chain d. of these random copolymers on Au is unfortunately not high enough to preclude any contact between the P2VP block of the block copolymer and the Au surface. Interestingly, gold nanoparticles coated by the random copolymer with FPS=0.4 were dispersed in the P2VP domain, while those with FPS=0.52 were located at the interface. A simple calcn. for the adsorption energy to the interface of the nanoparticles with different surface arrangements of PS and P2VP ligands supports evidence for the rearrangement of thiol terminated homopolymers. An upper limit est. of the adsorption energy of nanoparticles uniformly coated with a random arrangement of PS and P2VP ligands where a 10% surface area was occupied by P2VP -mers or chains was ∼1 kBT, which indicates that such nanoparticles are unlikely to be segregated along the interface, in contrast to the exptl. results for nanoparticles with mixed ligand-coated surfaces.

Gold nanoparticles (Au-PS) coated with an areal chain d. Σ of end-attached polystyrene (PS) chains of different mol. wts. (Mn) are added to a lamellar diblock copolymer of poly(styrene-b-2-vinylpyridine) (PS-b-P2VP) to det. the crit. areal chain d. ΣC below which the Au-PS nanoparticles adsorb to the PS-b-P2VP interface. Gold nanoparticles coated by thiol end functional polystyrene homopolymers (PS-SH) with Mn ranging from 1.5 to 13 kg/mol are synthesized with various areal densities of PS-SH chains on the nanoparticle surface. The particles are incorporated into a PS-b-P2VP diblock copolymer with Mn = 196 kg/mol. The P2VP block has a more favorable interaction with a bare gold particle surface than does the PS block, and this interaction becomes important as the coverage of gold particles by PS-SH decreases, leading to adsorption of the Au-PS to the interface below a crit. areal chain d. ΣC. ΣC Decreases from 3.1 to 0.9 chains/nm2 as the Mn of PS-SH chains increases from 1.5 to 13 kg/mol, leading to a scaling relation, .sum.C ∼ Rg-1 ∼ Mn-0.6, which is very different from the behavior expected for polymer chains tethered to a flat surface, .sum.C ∼ Rg-2 ∼ Mn-1, where Rg is the radius of gyration of the end-attached chains. A simple scaling relationship, ΣC ∼ ((R + Rg)/RRg)2 that takes into account the high curvature of the Au nanoparticle core of radius R, is derived and is shown to describe the data very well. For Σ ≈ ΣC, there is a slight tendency for the larger particles within the particle size distribution to adsorb preferentially to the PS/P2VP interface, a tendency that can be qual. understood by the fact that the absorption free energy per particle is predicted to scale roughly as R2.

The spontaneous organization of multicomponent micrometer-sized colloids or nanocrystals into superlattices is of scientific importance for understanding the assembly process on the nanometer scale and is of great interest for bottom-up fabrication of functional devices. In particular, co-assembly of two types of nanocrystal into binary nanocrystal superlattices (BNSLs) has recently attracted significant attention, as this provides a low-cost, programmable way to design meta materials with precisely controlled properties that arise from the organization and interactions of the constituent nanocrystal components. Although challenging, the ability to grow and manipulate large-scale BNSLs is crit. for extensive exploration of this new class of material. The authors report a general method of growing centimeter-scale, uniform membranes of BNSLs that can readily be transferred to arbitrary substrates. The authors' method is based on the liq.-air interfacial assembly of multicomponent nanocrystals and circumvents the limitations assocd. with the current assembly strategies, allowing integration of BNSLs on any substrate for the fabrication of nanocrystal-based devices. The authors demonstrate the construction of magnetoresistive devices by incorporating large-area (1.5 mm × 2.5 mm) BNSL membranes; their magneto transport measurements clearly show that device magnetoresistance is dependent on the structure (stoichiometry) of the BNSLs. The ability to transfer BNSLs also allows the construction of free-standing membranes and other complex architectures that were not accessible previously.

Highly asym. block copolymers forming spherical microdomains arrange in a hexagonal lattice as a monolayer, while the bulk equil. structure is body-centered cubic. A complex transition from two- to three-dimensional packing in thin films of spherical-domain poly(styrene-b-2-vinylpyridine) was measured by grazing-incidence small-angle x-ray scattering and TEM. The monolayer hexagonal symmetry persists through three layers, with close-packed AB and ABA stacking in films two and three layers thick. At four layers, coexistence between an equil. hcp. symmetry and a metastable face-centered orthorhombic structure is obsd. As the no. of layers is further increased from 4 to 23, the hexagonal phase vanishes, and the symmetry of the face-centered orthorhombic phase deforms to approach asymptotically a structure similar to a body-centered cubic lattice with the closest-packed (110) plane oriented parallel to the substrate. Self-consistent-field theory calcns. demonstrate that these thickness-dependent packing symmetries result from a competition between the packing preferred in the bulk with that at the interfaces.

The effect of blending small wt. fractions of low mol. wt. majority block homopolymer on the structure of multilayer films of spherical morphol. poly(styrene-b-2vinylpyridine) [PS-P2VP] has been studied. The structure of the films was characterized with grazing-incidence small-angle X-ray scattering (GISAXS) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). In multilayer films of PS-P2VP, competition between hexagonal packing of the spherical domains preferred at the surfaces with the BCC (110) packing preferred by the internal layers leads to a transition in the packing symmetry as the no. of sphere layers (n) is increased. Neat PS-P2VP exhibits hcp. (HCP) symmetry up through n = 4, but at four layers coexistence of hexagonal and face-centered orthorhombic phases is obsd. At n = n* = 5 the face-centered orthorhombic structure (FCO) is the stable phase. On increasing n further, the FCO phase continuously distorts to approach the arrangement of the BCC (110) plane. We observe that blending a small wt. fraction of low mol. wt. PS homopolymer with PS-P2VP suppresses this transition and stabilizes the hcp. arrangement beyond four layers. Moreover, n* increases with increasing wt. fraction of incorporated homopolymer for the small wt. fractions of homopolymer used in this study. Self-consistent-field theory simulations designed to mimic the exptl. system corroborate that n* is expected to increase and show that the PS homopolymer segregates to the interstices of the HCP unit cell. This suggests that the homopolymer reduces the stretching of the PS block and the free energy penalty of HCP relative to BCC inner layers. This result is consistent with the hypothesis that the excessive stretching requirement in an HCP arrangement is the cause of its higher free energy as compared to the BCC lattice.

A nanoparticle radius ratio dependent study is reported of the formation of binary nanoparticle superlattices (BNSLs) of CdTe and CdSe quantum dots. While keeping all other parameters identical in the system, the effective nanoparticle radius ratio, γeff, was tuned to gave 5 different BNSL structures, AlB2, cub-NaZn13, ico-NaZn13, CaCu5, and MgZn2. For each structure, γeff is located close to a local max. of its space-filling factor, based on a model for space filling principles. The ability to select specific BNSLs based solely on γeff, highlighting the role of entropic forces as a driver for self-assembly is demonstrated.

We studied the effect of temp. on self-assembly of monodisperse colloidal nanocrystals into single-component and binary superlattices. Temp., which serves as a weighting factor for the internal energy (U) and entropy (S) contributions to the Helmholtz free energy F = U - TS, allows tailoring relative wts. of the interparticle interactions and free-vol. entropy during the formation of nanocrystal superlattices. Temp. also provides a convenient tool for directing self-assembly of nanocrystals toward desired superlattice structures. We found that temp. strongly affects the structures of binary superlattices self-assembled from the mixts. of CdSe + PbS nanocrystals and PbSe + Pd nanocrystals. In the former case, small Hamaker consts. for CdSe and PbS nanocrystals led to a relatively simple phase diagram, including only high-d. NaZn13-, AlB2-, and NaCl-type binary superlattices. In contrast, binary superlattices self-assembled at different temps. from PbSe and Pd nanocrystals showed a no. of low-d. complex phases stabilized by strong local van der Waals interactions between Pd nanocrystals. The structural diversity of nanoparticle superlattices is shown to be a result of the cooperative effect of the entropy-driven crystn. and the interparticle interactions. Both ΔU and TΔS terms assocd. with the superlattice formation should be of the same order of magnitude, with |ΔU| < |TΔS| for the assembly of CdSe and PbS nanocrystals and |ΔU| > |TΔS| for the PbSe and Pd nanocrystals.

A review. In this review we present a summary of recent progress achieved in examg. the equil. and dynamical properties of concd. solns. of two novel kinds of soft matter systems: star-shaped polymers and starburst mols. known as dendrimers. The two systems share a host of interesting properties. The both consist of highly branched polymers, they allow for tuning of their properties through modification of the macromol. architecture and they are both representatives of a quite novel class of colloidal particles, termed ultrasoft colloids. On the other hand there are also important differences, reflecting the fundamental difference in their architecture. It will be shown that a combination of scattering techniques and rheol. with computer simulations and anal. methods from the realm of theor. physics can shed light on the unusual properties of such systems. In this fashion, new ways appear for the manipulation of soft matter systems under external influences and promising perspectives for the fabrication of new materials are opened up and the versatility in manipulating soft matter is underlined.

The assembly of body centered-cubic (bcc.) superlattices of org. ligand-coated nanocrystals is discussed. First, examples of bcc. superlattices of dodecanethiol-capped Au nanocrystals and oleic acid-capped PbS and PbSe nanocrystals are presented and examd. by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and grazing incidence small-angle X-ray scattering (GISAXS). These superlattices tend to orient on their densest (110) superlattice planes and exhibit a significant amt. of {112} twinning. The same nanocrystals deposit as monolayers with hexagonal packing, and these thin films can coexist with thicker bcc. superlattice layers, even though there is no hexagonal plane in a bcc. lattice. Both the preference of bcc. in bulk films over the denser face-centered cubic (fcc.) superlattice structure and the transition to hexagonal monolayers can be rationalized in terms of packing frustration of the ligands. A model is presented to calc. the difference in entropy assocd. with capping ligand packing frustration in bcc. and fcc. superlattices.

The authors propose a heuristic explanation for the numerous nonclose-packed crystal structures obsd. in various colloidal systems. By developing an analogy between soap froths and the soft coronas of fuzzy colloids, the authors provide a geometrical interpretation of the free energy of soft spheres. Within this picture, the close-packing rule assocd. with hard-core interactions and positional entropy of particles is frustrated by a min.-area principle assocd. with the soft tail and internal entropy of the soft coronas. The authors also discuss these ideas in terms of crystal architecture and pair distribution functions and analyze the phase diagram of a model hard-sphere-square-shoulder system within the cellular theory. The A15 lattice, known to be area minimizing, is favored for a reasonable range of model parameters and so it is among the possible equil. states for a variety of colloidal systems. Also in the case of short-range convex potentials the A15 and other nonclose-packed lattices coexist over a broad ranges of densities, which could make their identification difficult.

Self-assembly of lead sulfide nanocrystals has been studied in real time using in situ grazing-incidence X-ray scattering. Following the first appearance of an ordered arrangement, the superlattice underwent uniaxial contraction and collective rotation as it approached its final body-centered cubic structure. The nanocrystals became crystallog. aligned early in the overall self-assembly process, showing that nanocrystal ordering occurs on a faster timescale than superlattice densification. Synchrotron X-ray scattering is a viable method for studying self-assembly in its native environment, with ample time resoln. to ext. kinetic rates and observe intermediate configurations. The method could be used for real-time direction of self-assembly processes and to better understand the forces governing self-organization of soft materials.

The assembly of colloidal nanocrystals (NCs) into superstructures with long-range translational and orientational order is sensitive to the mol. interactions between ligands bound to the NC surface. The authors illustrate how ligand coverage on colloidal PbS NCs can be exploited as a tunable parameter to direct the self-assembly of superlattices with predefined symmetry. PbS NCs with dense ligand coverage assemble into fcc. superlattices whereas NCs with sparse ligand coverage assemble into bcc. superlattices which also exhibit orientational ordering of NCs in their lattice sites. Surface chem. characterization combined with d. functional theory calcns. suggest that the loss of ligands occurs preferentially on {100} than on reconstructed {111} NC facets. The resulting anisotropic ligand distribution amplifies the role of NC shape in the assembly and gives superlattices with translational and orientational order.

In this work, we present a joint exptl. and mol. dynamics simulations effort to understand and map the crystn. behavior of polyhedral nanoparticles assembled via the interaction of DNA surface ligands. In these systems, we systematically investigated the interplay between the effects of particle core (via the particle symmetry and particle size) and ligands (via the ligand length) on crystn. behavior. This investigation revealed rich phase diagrams, previously unobserved phase transitions in polyhedral crystn. behavior, and an unexpected symmetry breaking in the ligand distribution on a particle surface. To understand these results, we introduce the concept of a zone of anisotropy, or the portion of the phase space where the anisotropy of the particle is preserved in the crystn. behavior. Through comparison of the zone of anisotropy for each particle we develop a foundational roadmap to guide future investigations.

Polymer-based membranes play a key role in several industrially important gas sepn. technologies, e.g., removing CO2 from natural gas, with enormous economic and environmental impact. Here, we develop a novel hybrid membrane construct comprised entirely of nanoparticles grafted with polymers. These membranes are shown to have broadly tunable sepn. performance through variations in graft d. and chain length. Computer simulations show that the optimal NP packing forces the grafted polymer layer to distort, yielding regions of measurably lower polymer d. Multiple exptl. probes confirm that these materials have the predicted increase in "polymer free vol.", which explains their improved sepn. performance. These polymer-grafted NP materials thus represent a new template for rationally designing membranes with desirable sepn. abilities coupled with improved aging characteristics in the glassy state and enhanced mech. behavior.

A model giving the conformation of a star-shaped polymer is proposed and takes into account the radial variation of the monomer concn. φ(r). For an isolated star when increasing r (at the center of the star r = 0), the variation of φ(r) is first given by a const. value (r < f1/2 l), then has a (r/l)-1 variation (for f1/2 l < r < f1/2 v-1 l), and finally a (r/l)-4/3 variation (for r > f1/2 v-1 l); where f is the no. of branches and v and l are the excluded vol. and the length assocd. to a monomer. For all these cases, it is shown that the size of a branch is always larger than that of a linear polymer made of N monomers. Beyond the overlapping concn. the star conformation is obtained from two characteristic lengths essentially: radius χ(c), inside which the branches of the other stars do not penetrate, defines a domain where the conformation of a star is similar to that of an isolated one; beyond χ(c) the interpenetration of branches is characterized by a screening length very similar to that found for semidilute solns. of linear polymers. For all these regimes the variation of the size of a star is predicted as a function of N, f, v and c.

We examine the structure of densely grafted polymer layers grown from the surfaces of spherical nanoparticles over a broad range of graft densities and chain lengths. Dynamic light scattering (DLS) expts. show that the hydrodynamic thickness of the polymer layer, h, scales as h .varies. N4/5 for short chains and high grafting densities, i.e., in the concd. polymer brush (CPB) regime, whereas h .varies. N3/5 for long enough chains (semidilute polymer brush, SDPB). The mean field theory of Wijmans and Zhulina is able to collapse approx. all of our data and those in the existing literature (even on other polymers) into an apparently universal form. From these findings, we conclude that the result h .varies. N4/5 for the CPB is an intermediate crossover scaling, relevant to particles of finite curvature, analogous to the h .varies. N obsd. for concd. flat brushes. Second, the scaling h .varies. N3/5 uniquely reflects the increased space available to the chain segments as one proceeds away from a curved grafting surface. Under these situations, the chains experience less packing frustration as compared to a planar brush, and the semidilute polymer brush shows scaling behavior analogous to chains in good solvent, even though the chains are much more extended.

Similar hybrid particles were studied with respect to the influence of graft chain length Lc on hydrodynamic diam. Dh in dil. suspension and on colloidal crystn. in more concd. suspension. The av. radius r0 of SiPs was 65 nm, and the surface d. σ0 of PMMA grafts at the SiP surface was about 0.7 chains/nm2 (about 36 000 chains per particle). The hydrodynamic thickness of the swollen brush layer h (=Dh/2 - r0) was qual. interpretable by a modified Daoud-Cotton-type scaling model. Namely, for short graft chains, h obeyed the universal relation, h[1 + (h/2r0)] ∼ Lcσ01/2, applicable to concd. polymer brushes on flat and spherical surfaces, and for chains longer than a crit. length, h showed pos. deviations from this linear relation, indicating the brush layer getting into the semidilute polymer brush regime. Suspensions of the hybrid particles showed a phase transition from a (disordered) fluid to a fully crystd. system with a narrow fluid/crystal coexisting regime. The crit. concn. of crystn. (m.p.) decreased with increasing graft chain length, and the nearest-neighbor interparticle distance Ddis in the crystal approached to a micrometer scale as the graft mol. wt. reached 500 000. Good correlation was obsd. between Dh and Ddis such that Ddis = (1.15 ± 0.05)Dh. Confocal laser scanning microscopic observation suggested that the colloidal crystal generally include both hcp. The (hcp) and face-centered cubic (fcc) lattice arrangements with the fcc arrangement likely to increase with increasing chain length.

Travesset, Alex
